summary: A talk by Richard Stallman discussing the principles of free software, the dangers of proprietary software, and the impact of software patents and globalization.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen displaying the text "Richard Stallman, Free Software Foundation, inc. http://www.fsf.org" in yellow and white font. The scene transitions to a man with a beard and long hair, wearing a green shirt, sitting in a room filled with papers and books. He is speaking, and subtitles in Italian appear on the screen, translating to "I am a person who has had experiences in a community of programmers in the 70s, we practiced the sharing of software, and it was a good way of living, and then the community was destroyed." The man gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The background shows a window with a grid pattern, and various items, including a pink bag, are visible on a shelf behind him. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere throughout, focusing on the man's narrative about his experiences in the programming community.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a ringing sound. A male speaker then describes his experience in a 1970s programmer community where software was shared, portraying it as a good way of life, before stating that the community was later destroyed.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a beard and wearing a green shirt is seated in a cluttered room filled with stacks of papers and books. He appears to be engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The room has a window with a grid pattern, allowing natural light to filter in, and a pink bag is visible on a shelf behind him. Throughout the video, Italian subtitles appear on the screen, providing translations of his speech. The subtitles discuss the man's experiences with proprietary software and his preference for free software, emphasizing the freedom and community aspects of using free software. The man's expressions and gestures convey his passion and conviction about the topic. The overall atmosphere of the video is one of earnest discussion and advocacy for free software.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker recalling a negative experience with proprietary software, leading him to declare, "I refuse to live that life." He speaks about building an entirely new world of software for freedom. This is followed by the sound of a wind chime. The speaker then defines free software as software that gives users freedom, elaborating on freedoms such as running the program, studying it, and making changes. He emphasizes the freedom to help one's neighbor and community by sharing and improving the software. The clip concludes with the speaker starting a sentence, "You know, Linux…"

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a laptop screen displaying a red and white sticker with a barcode and some text. A person's hand is seen gesturing over the laptop, emphasizing the importance of freedom, as indicated by the Italian text "la vita presenta molte possibilità di perdere le tue libertà" (life presents many possibilities of losing your freedoms). The hand continues to gesture, reinforcing the message with the text "e quindi dobbiamo difendere la nostra libertà sempre" (and therefore we must always defend our freedom). The narrative progresses with the hand pointing to the laptop, accompanied by the text "ma per difendere la nostra libertà dobbiamo valorizzarla" (but to defend our freedom we must value it). The hand then moves away, and the text "e per valorizzarla dobbiamo capire di cosa si tratta" (and to value it we must understand what it is about) appears. The scene transitions to a black screen with the text "quindi possiamo capire perché è importante" (so we can understand why it is important). The video then shifts to an illustration of a bull and a penguin, both wearing superhero costumes with the letters "GPL" on them, symbolizing the GNU General Public License. The text "e combattere per mantenerla quando è minacciata" (and fight to maintain it when it is threatened) is displayed. The video concludes with a black screen displaying the text "Il Sistema Operativo GNU/Linux" (The GNU/Linux Operating System) in yellow, highlighting the importance of the GNU/Linux operating system in the context of freedom and the GPL.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker reflecting on life's challenges to freedom. He emphasizes the need to "defend our freedom constantly" and value it to understand its importance and be ready to fight for it when threatened. As he concludes, a bicycle bell rings briefly. The speaker then refers to a specific time period: "In 1900..."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a beard and wearing a green t-shirt is seated in a cluttered office, surrounded by stacks of papers and books. He is speaking passionately, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The text on the screen is in Italian, with phrases such as "nel 1983 ho annunciato di voler sviluppare" (in 1983 I announced that I wanted to develop), "un sistema operativo libero" (a free operating system), and "per usare il tuo computer hai bisogno di un sistema operativo" (to use your computer you need an operating system). The man discusses the importance of a free operating system, highlighting the lack of freedom in proprietary systems and the need for a free OS to live in freedom. He also mentions his role as a systems programmer and the ability to involve many others in the project. The office environment is busy and somewhat chaotic, with a window in the background letting in natural light. The man's facial expressions and gestures convey his enthusiasm and conviction about the topic he is discussing.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip opens with a single male speaker announcing his plan to develop a free software operating system in 1983, stating that "in order to run your computer, you need an operating system". He explains the problem of all existing systems being "proprietary, non-free," and the need for a free one to "live in freedom." As an operating system developer, he felt he had a chance, especially with help.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a beard and long hair, wearing a green shirt, seated in a cluttered room filled with stacks of papers and books. He appears to be speaking, gesturing with his hands, and occasionally looking directly at the camera. The room has a window with blinds, and various items are scattered around, including a pink bag and a whiteboard with notes and pictures. The man's expressions and gestures suggest he is engaged in a conversation or presentation. The video includes text overlays in Italian, such as "sono un hacker e sono stato un hacker nello spirito dagli anni '60" (I am a hacker and I have been a hacker in spirit since the 1960s) and "essere hacker vuol dire fare cose con uno spirito di giocosa intelligenza" (Being a hacker means doing things with a playful intelligence). The text provides context to the man's discussion, emphasizing his long-standing involvement in hacking and the spirit of playful intelligence associated with it. The video transitions between close-up shots of the man and wider shots of the room, maintaining a consistent focus on his expressions and the cluttered environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker explaining that "GNU/Linux" is the combination of the "GNU operating system" and a program called Linux, spoken in an informative tone. This is briefly interrupted by the sound of a ringing bell, before the speaker returns, identifying as a hacker since the 1960s and explaining that "to be a hacker means to do things in a spirit of playful cleverness" and to explore the limits. The speaker continues on to say that "you can be a hacker in all sorts of different media".

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a beard and long hair, wearing a green shirt, sitting in a cluttered office filled with stacks of papers and books. He is speaking and gesturing with his hands, emphasizing his points. The text on the screen is in Italian, with phrases like "programmare è solo uno di questi" (programming is just one of these) and "quando avevamo programmatori in 4 continenti" (when we had programmers in 4 continents). The man discusses the impact of globalization and the Free Software movement, with text such as "La Globalizzazione" (Globalization) and "il FS rende difficile l'esistenza delle megacorporazioni" (FS makes it difficult for megacorporations to exist). The video transitions between the man speaking and black screens with yellow text, including "il FS facilita un altro tipo di business" (FS facilitates another type of business) and "il FS ti da la possibilità di assumere qualcuno" (FS gives you the possibility to hire someone). The man continues to speak, with text like "nelle loro aree di esperienza" (in their areas of expertise) appearing on the screen. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere, focusing on the man's discussion of programming, globalization, and the Free Software movement.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker saying "programming is just one of them...". His tone is conversational. He claims "pirates are people who attack ships" and, in contrast, "people who share software are good neighbors." He believes "free software" shows how globalization "can be a good thing." There is a gentle, intermittent ringing sound in the background. The speaker continues, noting that the "free software movement has been global since the 80s" and now spans "six continents." He contrasts "globalization of power" with the "globalization of voluntary cooperation." The speaker explains that "free software makes it hard to have global mega-corporations." He suggests it facilitates "a different kind of business, providing support and services to people in your area" because "free software" allows one to hire someone to make changes. Many small companies offer support in their areas of expertise, typically to "people in their region," "people who speak the same language" etc. Finally, the ringing sound reappears.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a beard and long hair, wearing a green shirt, is seen speaking in an indoor setting with a window and blinds in the background. He appears to be discussing the implications of teaching non-free software to young people, as indicated by the Italian subtitles that translate to "teaching young people non-free software." The man gestures with his hands while speaking, emphasizing his points. The subtitles continue to provide context to his speech, mentioning the consequences of such education, including the loss of freedom and money. The man's expressions and gestures suggest a passionate and serious tone as he addresses the topic. The setting remains consistent throughout the video, with the man positioned in front of the window, and the focus remains on his message about the importance of free software education.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the implications of teaching children to use non-free software, claiming it trains them to be under the domination of software owners. He argues that this could lead to extra work or loss of freedom and money for the children as adults, directing society into a rut of non-free software.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with a beard and long hair, wearing a green shirt, is seated in a cluttered room filled with stacks of papers and books. He appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, as indicated by his hand gestures and facial expressions. The room has a window with blinds, and the lighting suggests it is daytime. Throughout the video, Italian subtitles appear on the screen, providing context to his speech. The subtitles discuss the importance of collaboration in scientific research, the risks to the spirit of scientific cooperation, and the influence of private research funds. The man emphasizes the need for control over one's computer and the implications of software ownership. The setting remains consistent, with the man seated in the same position, and the background cluttered with papers and books, creating an atmosphere of intellectual engagement and discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker discussing the "free software movement" and its inspiration from "scientific cooperation." He continues, noting that people are taking "the inspiration back to science," and asserts that the "spirit of scientific cooperation is endangered today" due to "corporate funding for research." He suggests that "government agencies and everybody ought to switch to free software" so users can control their computers, as proprietary software gives control to the owner instead. Then, the sound of a ringing telephone briefly dominates before the clip concludes.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a beard and long hair, wearing a green shirt, sitting in a room with a window and blinds in the background. He appears to be speaking, as his mouth moves and his facial expressions change throughout the video. The room is cluttered with stacks of papers and magazines behind him. Throughout the video, yellow text appears on the screen in Italian, providing context to his speech. The text translates to: "so there will be only one patent to protect it," "it is the result of many ideas put together," "even if you develop a new software package," "where it is possible to patent software ideas," "and it is a completely different thing from copyright," and "but patents work differently." The man's expressions and the text suggest he is discussing intellectual property, specifically patents and copyrights, and how they apply to software development. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere, focusing on the man's discussion and the informative text.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker criticizing the naive myth of the patent system. He mentions developing something innovative, “the patent", and cautions that this isn't the case for software. He explains that a product that isn't trivially simple has different ideas combined, and that developers are in danger from software patents. He explains that a developer in a country that allows software to be patented "can be sued for the software he writes". He contrasts this to the system of copyright. He argues that "patents work very differently," and that a person could get sued "for writing and for using a program yourself."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a long beard and dark hair, wearing a green shirt, speaking directly to the camera. He is seated in front of a background with horizontal blinds, suggesting an indoor setting. Throughout the video, yellow text appears at the bottom of the screen in Italian, providing context to his speech. The text translates to "Microsoft is trying to obtain patents on 'de facto' standards" and "for example, you know Microsoft .Net," followed by "Microsoft is trying to patent some basic ideas in .Net." The man's facial expressions and mouth movements indicate that he is actively engaged in delivering his message, which appears to be a discussion or commentary on Microsoft's patenting practices related to technology standards and the .Net framework. The video maintains a consistent visual style, with the man remaining the central focus against the backdrop of the blinds.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker expressing concern about Microsoft's patent applications, specifically mentioning ".net" and the company attempting to patent "important basic ideas". The speaker sounds serious and critical. There are no discernible background sounds or music.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a beard and long hair, wearing a green shirt, speaking directly to the camera in an indoor setting with a window featuring horizontal blinds in the background. Throughout the video, Italian text appears at the bottom of the screen, providing context to his speech. The text translates to "MS is designing a new universal file format," "it is an extended version of XML," "due to the large number of patents they possess," "large corporations exert pressure to force others," "Therefore, one should not think that software patents," and "protect small developers from competition." The man's facial expressions and gestures suggest he is discussing the implications of Microsoft's new file format and the impact of patents on small developers. The setting remains consistent, with no significant changes in the background or lighting, maintaining a focused and informative atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Microsoft designing a new file format and applying for a patent on it. The speaker continues by mentioning that mega-corporations use patents to pressure others to cross-license, and software patents would not protect small developers from competition. The overall tone is informative and slightly critical of mega-corporations.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a long beard and dark hair, wearing a green shirt, speaking directly to the camera in an indoor setting with a dark, horizontal-striped background. Throughout the video, yellow subtitles appear at the bottom of the screen, providing translations of his speech in Italian. The subtitles discuss the evaluation of a European directive on software patents, mentioning that the directive was written by the Business Software Alliance and was distributed in a Word format, which led to the omission of corrections and hidden information. The man appears to be explaining the implications of this directive, emphasizing the importance of understanding who wrote it. The setting remains consistent, with no significant changes in the background or the man's position, maintaining a focused and informative atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing a directive on software patents being considered in Europe. He says the text of the directive was written by the Business Software Alliance. The speaker says it was possible to know that because it was released in word format, they forgot to remove deleted portions of the text and other hidden information, which people were then able to look at, and see who really wrote it. The speaker says it was someone who works for the business software alliance.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man with a beard and long hair, wearing a green shirt, speaking in an indoor setting with a window and blinds in the background. He is surrounded by stacks of newspapers, suggesting a casual, possibly home office environment. Throughout the video, the man gestures with his hands, emphasizing his points as he speaks. The text on the screen is in Italian, with phrases such as "L'assenza di brevetti in Europa è un vantaggio" (The absence of patents in Europe is an advantage) and "e io spero che gli Stati Uniti rinsaviscono e si liberino" (and I hope that the United States wakes up and frees itself). These texts indicate that the man is discussing the advantages of not having patents in Europe and expressing hope for the United States to change its stance. The video concludes with the man being embraced by another person, suggesting a moment of camaraderie or support. The overall atmosphere is one of earnest discussion and personal connection.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing software patents, emphasizing how their absence in Europe benefits European developers as they can't be sued at home. He contrasts this with the US system, saying anyone worldwide can obtain US software patents and "attack us poor Americans."  He expresses a hope that the US will "wise up" and eliminate its harmful policy.  The clip concludes with the distinct ringing of bells.
